field_edited_text.value:
Fells Point, looking south, Broadway, Recreation Pier

renovated and vacant warehouses con-
verted to condominiums. At the same time,
there is still considerable industrial and
maritime activity in the area as witnessed
by the Arundel Corp. concrete plant on
the east, the Allied Chemical Co. plant in
the west, and the various warehouses and
tugboat companies which line the shore-
line. The area also supports a thriving
commercial trade with many taverns,
antique shops, and an open stall market
which attracts customers from the entire
metropolitan area.

The Canton waterfront extends from
Chester Street eastward along Boston Street
to Clinton Street. From the late 18th cen-
tury the Canton Shoreline has been primar-
ily industrial. It was the site for one of the
earliest shipyards, Stodder Brothers, which
was responsible for the construction of the
U.S. Frigate Constellation in 1797. Boston
Street was for many years known as
“Canners Row”’ because of the number of
canning firms located on or near the water-
front. Although the Canton community
extended to the north side of Boston Street
the waterfront was cut-off from public use
because of the industrial activities. It has
only been in the last fifteen years, since the
removal of a number of older buildings in
preparation for the once proposed 1-83,
that the shoreline has become visable and
available to the general public.



Development History

Settled in 1730 by William Fell, Fells
Point was one of the three original settle-
ments which joined together in 1797 to
form the City of Baltimore. Fell had rightly
recognized the unique advantage for ship-
ping that the area’s stable shoreline and
deep water offered. By the mid 18th cen-
tury, Fells Point dominated the other two
settlements, Baltimore Town and Jones
Town, in waterborne commerce and ship-
building. The waterfront was lined with
piers and warehouses, and the community
supported a mixture of commerce and
residential development. Shipbuilding was
a major industry, especially to the east
along Boston Street and in neighboring
Canton.

Most of the Canton waterfront east of
Harris Creek was originally settled by Cap-
tain John O’Donnell who arrived in the
area in 1785. Within a few years O’'Donnell
was the owner of over 2,500 acres stretching
from Harris Creek eastward into the Can-
ton industrial area. His son, Columbus,
joined with Peter Cooper in 1827 to form
the Canton Company. Cooper, In turn,
developed the Boston Street Ironworks,
located at the current site of the American
Can Company. For the next hundred years
the Canton waterfront would be a center
for industrial activity, including cannaries,
box manufacturing, railyards, and special-
ized steel equipment and plate fabrication.

In the 19th and early 20th centuries,
Fells Point was an important entry port for
the great influx of European immigrants.
While many remained only shortly in the
area, Fells Point still boasts a sizable Polish
and Eastern European community.

As technology changed, shipping and
maritime activities gradually moved to other
locations on the harbor. Today many for-
merly active piers have rotted away and a
number of warehouses stand ready to be
renovated into commercial and residential
uses.

In the 1960s an alignment for the Inter-
state 83 expressway was chosen that would
have routed the roadway through the cen-
ter of Fells Point. The City purchased
houses and land to make way for the road.
Realizing the area’s historic character and
the potential for residential and commer-
cial development, citizen’s groups opposed
the alignment and urged the City to seek
other routes. The City responded by pro-
posing that the expressway be built in a
tunnel south of Fells Point. This new align-
ment allowed the houses previously ac-
quired to be sold for rehabilitation. Subse-
quently, the escalating cost of highway con-
struction has prompted the City to propose
lower cost alternatives.





90
